title: Does politics affect our daily lives? How? - Quora

response.answer_text: People usually don’t like to talk about politics. While many have their own unique reason, the fact of the matter is that most people don’t even know enough about politics so that they can have a meaningful discussion. That in itself is a sad problem of our society, as many people simply believe that politics are detached from their daily lives, and so they don’t give it enough thought. The truth could not be further from that point of view. Politicsare in fact so much intertwined with our daily lives, that it can easily be the most deciding factor in almost everything we do, the thing is most people don’t know or don’t care until it directly affects them. Politics are important, so much so, that every law that we follow has been written by politicians. Even the products that we have in our stores are allowed in our country by politics and cost a certain amount due to the laws that are written by politicians. The future of every country is its people, and so people should be aware of how much politics does affect and can affect their lives. To be perfectly aware just how politics can shape our surroundings, think about the situation of women in Saudi Arabia for instance. Their women were not allowed to drive their cars without a male guardian present. Only today in 2018 has the law been changed so that women can drive the cars without males present in the car. This is a huge difference compared to America and the rest of the western world, where man and women have equal rights.  Another great example of how politics affects our daily lives is if you are a student that wants to study abroad and if you are not part of the European Union or a country that does not have direct access with the country where you want to study, you will then need a visa. The trick is you could be denied that visa, and so your dreams of studying in that particular country have come to an end. This is all because of how politics of your country and the country where you want to study come to terms. If you are lucky that both countries and their politics are on equal terms than you can freely move from one to another without too much paperwork and hassle, but if they aren’t then tough luck. In conclusion people need to be aware of just how much politics affect their lives, and they should not just go and vote for one side all the time, but in fact, they should research all the sides of the political spectrum in their country, and get to know everything that their political party wants to change and how it will directly affect them and their daily lives. A country without an educated populace about how their politics works will rarely advance towards a greater good, and will always lead down to a corrupt government which is not good either for the country or for its people.

This one is quite easy. Politics has a very strong impact on the way that people think and the way people operate within a complex social and political system. The connection between cultures and ideologies must be manifest through the actions which we take which are political in nature, and if we do not allow the political to influence the societal then we have a problem because society, without a political system on which it is predicated, cannot thrive or function because even unity must be enforced at some level. This is why I support the Democratic Party. Even though I do not consider myself a Democrat, and would rather call myself a leftist, it seems clear to me that the only way to achieve the so-called “leftist agenda” (as it is sometimes called by conservatives) is by electing officials who are predominantly Democratic in their political orientation. Issues like free speech, abortion, political correctness and immigration are just some of the things that need to be addressed in our society, and it seems like it's the conservatives who want to prevent us from having real life discussions on these subjects. The reason for this may have to do with the conservative agenda, which is not interested in diversity of opinion (though they may claim otherwise) but are much rather interested in being dominant on the societal level through the influences of religion and the state. This is why I think we need to have a change in the way that we operate within society so that we can accommodate these changes and allow for real change to take place when the common forms of change haven't. The best way to push this is to make conservatives get out of the way so that other groups of people can thrive, and we do not need the help of any conservative. What we need are people who are willing to help those who are suffering and who are willing to lift them up out of poverty and starvation. Thank you.

There’s a story about G.K. Chesterton that I’ve heard, but can’t find the reference for, so I’ll post it from memory. He was offered a job writing a column for a newspaper as long as he didn’t write about religion or politics. He took the job and said that he then spent 20 years writing about religion and politics; because religion is man’s relationship with the ultimate questions, and politics is mans relationship with his fellow man. Politics is the term we use for what happens in government, but it is also what happens in day to day life. You have give and take (or should), you use politeness even when you don’t know people (or you know and don’t like them) because it makes interactions easier. To act altruistically because you are a good person, but even if not because you want the people you help to someday help you if you need it. If you are humble, you support those who may someday take over your job, (whether you want to leave or not) because others helped you. Interactions between people often have an aspect of power. This person can do something to harm that person, so that person has to watch out. Sometimes this is real power, and people with often come to think they deserve the power to rule even in areas outside their domain. To take a leaf from fiction, there was a TV show many years ago called _The Paper Chase_ about law students. The contracts professor gives them a set of very difficult questions to answer over a weekend. The students rush around trying to find reference material, discovering it checked out by other students or just missing. They try their best, and only answer a few questions. Then they get together, and negotiate answers and reference material, bartering on the difficulty of what they have to offer vs. what the others have, and in the end, everyone in the class has all of the answers. When asked by the professor what they learned, only one realizes that they used contracts to share the answers, and the professor agrees, pointing out that contracts aren’t just in a classroom but a real thing in life. Politics isn’t just in the government, but it is a real thing in our interactions. It’s a shame that the elected officials aren’t taking any lessons from the people they govern.

I will answer from my reading of Hegel’s Philosophy of Right (1821): When we speak of politics, we speak of our national government, and therefore we speak of our Constitution. In each nation, the national Constitution carefully defines the Freedoms that the citizens (or subjects) of that government will allow, and will fight for in actual combat. Now — Hegel says that Freedom is the main factor in life that makes us who we are. The level of Freedom that we have — like the level of guidance that we have — all of this forms our young Personalities so that we develop into who we are. Hegel concludes, that I owe everything I am to the Freedoms that I have enjoyed under my national Constitution — therefore, I literally owe my nation military service whenever I am asked. I might be killed when performing my military service duties — but that is precisely what I owe to my nation the source of my Freedom — my very own life. The blood of the patriots of my nation gave their lives so that I can enjoy the Freedoms that make me who I am. So — politics is a matter of life and death. Now, what could be more relevant to our daily lives than matters of life and death? Every ordinary citizen wants to read his or her national Constitution, and understand the Freedoms and Rules of the nation. Our modern knowledge of politics begins and ends there. There’s my reading.
